elements.name: parentalResponsibilitiesDescription
elements.title:
Guardians make decisions about their child, including daily care and supervision, education, medical treatment, receiving information about the child from others, and protecting the childâ€™s legal and financial interests. These are examples of parental responsibilities. Guardians share parental responsibilities unless they have a court order or agreement that says otherwise.

Parental responsibilities may be shared with the guardians cooperating to make decisions jointly, exercised by only one guardian, or divided between more than one guardian with each having parental responsibilities over different decisions. You must carefully consider what is best for the child.

If there is more than one guardian for a child, an agreement or court order can help to make it clear who has certain parenting responsibilities and when.

The Family Law Act provides a list of `parental responsibilities` .

elements.name: allResponsibilitiesOrder
elements.description: If you get a court order that gives you all parental responsibilities for a child, it means that you get to make all decisions about a child and have full responsibility for a child. The child may have another guardian but the other guardian will not have parental responsibility for the child.

elements.name: ExplainResponsibilities
elements.title: You are not requesting all parental responsibilities. Explain the order you want about how parental responsibilities are to be exercised by the guardians.
elements.description:
You do not need to use any special wording. The key is to be clear about what you mean and what you are asking the court to order. If there is more than one child, be clear if there are differences in how parental responsibilities apply to each child.

Talk to a lawyer if you need help figuring out how parental responsibilities should be set up for your family.

elements.name: ChangeExplanationFAQ
elements.title: Family dynamics change and children grow up.  A parenting order that was made in the past may not make sense anymore. The court can only change an order if there has been a change in the needs or circumstances of the child since the original court order or written agreement was made, including a change in the circumstances of another person such as a parent.

elements.name: existingOrderChangeParentalResponsibilitiesDescription
elements.title: Describe the changes to parental responsibilities you are asking for
elements.description:
If there is more than one guardian for a child, a court order can help to make it clear who can make which parenting decisions and when. Parenting decisions may be made together, by only one guardian, or divided between more than one guardian. You must carefully consider which way is best for the child.

You do not need to use any special wording. The key is to be clear about what you mean and what you are asking the court to order.

elements.name: changeParentalTime
elements.description: Parenting time is the time each guardian spends with the child.  Guardians can arrange parenting time in any way that is in the best interests of the child.  Parenting time can be shared equally, or one guardian can have the child more of the time.

elements.name: existingOrderChildBestInterestDescription
elements.title: Describe why you believe the order you are asking for is in the child(ren)'s best interests.
elements.description:
When you make parenting arrangements, you must consider what is in the best interests of your child(ren). Every family situation is unique and the court needs to know why you believe the order you are asking for is best for your child(ren).

To determine what is in the child's best interests when making parenting arrangements, you must consider factors including:
  • The child's emotional health and well-being
  • The child's views, unless it would be inappropriate to consider them
  • The child's relationships with parents, guardians, and other important people
  • The history of care, and
  • The impact of any family violence

You do not need to use any special wording. The key is to be clear about why you think the court should make the parenting order.
